Question 2.Question: One of the reasons for an exceptional demand curve is the
Question 2.Explanation: An exception demand curve can also be called abnormal demand curve or super normal demand curve. It is a type of curve that does not conform with the normal law of demand. It is a curve showing a positive relationship instead of negative relationship between price and quantity demanded. The causes of an exceptional demand curve include, article of ostentation, inferior goods, band wagon effect, ignorance expectation of a future change in price e.t.c.

Question 21.Question: The Malthusian theory of population has been rendered ineffective by
Question 21.Explanation: Malthusian theory of population has been rendered ineffective by technical progress. Known forhiswork onpopulation growth, Thomas RobertMalthusargued that, left unchecked, apopulationwill outgrowitsresources. He discussed two ways to check apopulation: preventive checks, likethemoral restraint of postponing marriage, or positive checks, like famine, disease and warfare.

Question 22.Explanation: Environmental degradation is the deterioration of the environment through depletion of resources such as air, water and soil; the destruction of ecosystems; habitat destruction; the extinction of wildlife; and pollution. Question 23.Explanation: Industrialization is the period of social and economic change that transforms a human group from an agrarian society into an industrial society, involving the extensive re-organization of an economy for the purpose of manufacturing. Question 24.Explanation:

Question 34.Explanation: The circular flow of income or circular flow is a model of the economy in which the major exchanges are represented as flows of money, goods and services, etc. between economic agents. Outflow in circular flow of income are leakages or ejections.

Question 35.Explanation: Cost push inflationisinflation caused byan increase inpricesof inputs like labour, raw material, etc. The increased price of the factors of productionleadsto a decreased supply of these goods. Question 40.Question: A firm incurs short-run costs when
Question 40.Explanation: Firm incurs short run cost when inputs cannot be varied. A firm in the short run uses both fixed inputs and variable inputs. Costs that arise due to the use of fixed inputs are called fixed costs or overhead costs or unavoidable costs. Whether a firm produces or not it will have to incur fixed cost. Thus, fixed cost is independent of the level of output.

Question 50.Question: The price per unit of a commodity to a buyer is the same as the
Question 50.Explanation:
TR = P x Q ------ (1)

AR = TR/Q ------ (2)

Substitute TR for (p x q) in equation (2)

AR = (P x Q)/Q

AR = P

This means that the average revenue of a seller is always equal to the price per unit.
